Why Everyone's Talking About Alkaline Water

The health benefits of alkaline water are a hot topic, but does it live up to the hype? You've seen it on shelves and heard celebrities praise it, but let's look at what the science says.

Quick Answer: What Are the Potential Health Benefits of Alkaline Water?

Based on current research, alkaline water may offer several potential benefits:

  1. Acid Reflux Relief: May help deactivate pepsin, the enzyme that triggers reflux.
  2. Improved Hydration: Could reduce blood viscosity more effectively than regular water after exercise.
  3. Metabolic Health: Associated with better blood sugar and triglyceride levels in some studies.
  4. Bone Health Support: May help reduce calcium loss and support bone density.
  5. Better Sleep & Strength: Linked to improved sleep and muscle strength in postmenopausal women.

Important Note: Most studies are small-scale. While alkaline water appears safe for most healthy people, those with kidney disease should consult their doctor.

The truth is, your body already maintains a tight pH balance through your kidneys and lungs. However, the benefits of alkaline water may extend beyond pH. Advanced ionization technology can create hydrogen-rich water with antioxidant properties, filter contaminants, and add beneficial minerals.

In this review, we'll examine the science, explore how it's made, and help you decide if it's right for you. I'm Thai Cabados, and for over two decades, I've specialized in water filtration, bringing alkaline hydrogen water systems to the US. My goal is to give you the straight facts.

What Is Alkaline Water and How Does It Affect Body pH?

Let's start with the basics. The "alkaline" in alkaline water refers to its pH level, a measure of how acidic or alkaline a substance is on a scale from 0 to 14. Anything below 7 is acidic, 7 is neutral, and above 7 is alkaline.

Regular drinking water is typically around a neutral pH of 7.0. Alkaline water, however, has a higher pH, usually between 8 and 9.5. But true alkaline water is more than just its pH. It also contains alkaline minerals and often has a negative Oxidation-Reduction Potential (ORP), which measures its antioxidant potential. The more negative the ORP, the better it can neutralize harmful free radicals.

Natural vs. Produced Alkaline Water

Nature creates alkaline water when it flows over rocks and picks up minerals like calcium, magnesium, and potassium. However, most alkaline water today is made using electrolysis in water ionizers. These devices filter tap water to remove contaminants, then use an electrical charge to separate it into acidic and alkaline streams.

At Life Ionizers, our advanced systems do more than raise pH—they infuse the water with molecular hydrogen (H2), creating what we call "Live Hydrogen Water." Our proprietary technology is designed to maximize these beneficial properties, giving you more than just a higher pH number.

How your body maintains balance

Will drinking alkaline water change your body's pH? The short answer is no, and that's a good thing. Your body works hard to maintain a tight blood pH balance between 7.35 and 7.45. This is primarily managed by your kidneys and lungs.

When you drink alkaline water, your highly acidic stomach (pH 1.5-3.5) simply produces more acid to neutralize it, ensuring proper digestion. As the Mayo Clinic's expert opinion on body pH notes, alkaline water won't significantly alter your body's overall pH.

So, the health benefits of alkaline water aren't about changing your blood's pH. Instead, they likely come from its other properties: improved hydration, mineral content, and antioxidant capacity.

The Science Behind the Claimed Health Benefits of Alkaline Water

While the marketing hype around alkaline water sometimes races ahead of the science, there's genuine research happening that suggests real benefits. The current research landscape is a mix of promising small-scale studies and a need for larger human trials, but some early findings are compelling.

One of the most interesting aspects is its potential antioxidant properties, which come largely from dissolved molecular hydrogen (H2) in ionized water. Antioxidants are your body's cleanup crew, neutralizing free radicals that contribute to aging and cellular damage.

Unpacking the potential health benefits of alkaline water for digestion

For those with acid reflux, some of the most concrete research on the health benefits of alkaline water is here. Acid reflux involves stomach acid and an enzyme called pepsin traveling up into your esophagus. A 2012 medical study found that alkaline water with a pH of 8.8 can permanently inactivate pepsin, the main trigger for reflux symptoms. The study also showed it has an improved ability to buffer stomach acid, potentially offering therapeutic relief.

Beyond reflux, a 2018 study on gastrointestinal symptoms found that people who drank alkaline electrolyzed water saw modest improvements in stool consistency, suggesting it may aid overall digestive comfort.

The long-term health benefits of alkaline water: What the research says

Recent research has revealed intriguing patterns around metabolic health. A 2022 study in PLoS One followed 304 postmenopausal women and found that those who regularly drank alkaline water were significantly less likely to have metabolic syndrome—a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes.

Researchers observed several benefits in the alkaline water drinkers, including lower fasting blood sugar, better triglyceride-to-HDL cholesterol ratios, and improved blood pressure. Perhaps most surprisingly, these women also reported longer sleep duration and showed increased handgrip strength, a key indicator of overall vitality.

Even animal studies add to the picture. A 2020 mouse study on aging found that daily alkaline water intake improved markers of DNA aging at the cellular level. While mice aren't humans, this hints at potential anti-aging effects.

Bone Health and Hydration

The link between alkaline water and bone health is based on the theory that your body may pull calcium from bones to neutralize excess acid. Over time, this could weaken bones. A 2021 study on bone density in osteoporosis suggests alkaline water may help improve bone density, particularly in postmenopausal women. The minerals in alkaline water, like calcium and magnesium, are essential for strong bones, making it a risk-free way to support bone health.

Regarding hydration, a study in the Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition found that after exercise, athletes who drank electrolyzed alkaline water reduced their blood viscosity by 6.30%, compared to only 3.36% with regular water. Lower blood viscosity means blood flows more easily, delivering oxygen and nutrients more efficiently. This "super hydrating" property could lead to better energy levels and overall cellular function.

How Is Alkaline Water Made and Is It Cost-Effective?

Understanding how alkaline water is made helps you decide if it's a smart choice for your family. Nature creates it when water flows over mineral-rich rocks, but for most of us, technology is the answer.

The most effective method is through advanced water ionizers. These machines first filter your tap water to remove contaminants like chlorine and heavy metals. Then, the water undergoes electrolysis, where it flows over electrically charged plates. This separates the water into an acidic stream (useful for cleaning) and an alkaline stream for drinking. Importantly, this process enriches the alkaline water with dissolved molecular hydrogen (H2), a powerful antioxidant.

Our Life Ionizers use proprietary technology to maximize this molecular hydrogen concentration, ensuring every glass is what we call "Live Hydrogen Water"—water optimized for your health.

Now, let's talk cost. A home water ionizer is an upfront investment, but like a coffee machine, it pays for itself over time by providing unlimited, fresh, hydrogen-rich alkaline water on demand.

Here's how the options stack up:

Feature Regular Tap Water Home Ionizer System (Life Ionizers)
Cost Low per gallon, ongoing utility Higher upfront, minimal long-term
pH Level Usually 6.5-7.5 Customizable (8-11.5)
Hydrogen (H2) None High, consistent concentration
Antioxidants Minimal High (from H2 and negative ORP)
Filtration None at point of use Advanced multi-stage filtration
Convenience From the tap On-demand optimized water at home
Environmental No added packaging Minimal (periodic filter changes)

When considering quality, cost, and the actual health benefits of alkaline water, a home ionizer system offers robust value by delivering a comprehensive water solution.

Are There Risks or Side Effects to Consider?

An honest look at the health benefits of alkaline water must include potential concerns. The good news is that for most healthy people, drinking alkaline water is generally safe. Your body's pH-regulating systems are remarkably efficient.

That said, some situations warrant caution. Consuming water with an extremely high pH (above 10) could potentially cause skin and eye irritation, which is why responsible ionizers produce drinking water in a safe range of pH 8.5 to 9.5. While you might hear about metabolic alkalosis (the body becoming too alkaline), it's extremely rare to get this from drinking water.

There's also a theoretical concern that high pH water could interfere with stomach acid's role in digestion, but your stomach is designed to produce more acid as needed. Finally, the quality of the ionizer matters. Poorly designed units could introduce unwanted particles, which is why Life Ionizers uses high-quality, safe materials to ensure purity.

Who should be cautious with alkaline water?

While safe for most, certain individuals should be careful or consult a doctor before starting.

People with kidney disease or impaired kidney function must be cautious. Kidneys regulate the body's acid-base balance and filter minerals. When their function is compromised, this system fails. Research shows that for people with kidney disease, drinking ionized alkaline water with a pH higher than 9.8 carries a risk of developing hyperkalemia (high blood potassium), which can be dangerous. The medical consensus is clear: people with kidney disease should avoid alkaline water without medical supervision.

Individuals taking certain medications, such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid reflux, should also consult their doctor. Changing your stomach's pH could interfere with how some medications are absorbed or how they work.

The bottom line: If you have any pre-existing health conditions or take regular medication, talk to your healthcare provider first. This ensures you can safely explore the potential benefits without any unwanted surprises.

Frequently Asked Questions about Alkaline Water

Even after exploring the health benefits of alkaline water, you might still have questions. Here are the most common ones.

How much alkaline water should I drink per day?

There's no official recommendation specifically for alkaline water, so standard hydration guidelines are your baseline. Studies showing benefits used varying amounts, from 1-2 liters for general health and postmenopausal women to 4 liters for athletes.

My advice is to start slowly and listen to your body. Begin with a moderate pH of around 8.5 and see how you feel. Your body is smart and will tell you what feels right. As always, if you have health conditions, consult your doctor first.

Is alkaline water the same as hydrogen water?

This is a great question, as the terms are often confused. They describe different properties:

  • Alkaline water refers to its pH level (above 7), meaning it's less acidic.
  • Hydrogen water contains dissolved molecular hydrogen gas (H2), a powerful antioxidant.

Advanced water ionizers, like all Life Ionizers models, produce both at the same time. During electrolysis, molecular hydrogen is generated and dissolved into the alkaline water. This means you get the pH benefits and the antioxidant power of H2 in every glass. This combination is why we call our water "Live Hydrogen Water"—it's about delivering maximum health benefits.

Does alkaline water taste different from regular water?

Most people notice a difference, often describing it as smoother, cleaner, and silkier. Some detect a subtle sweetness from the beneficial minerals like calcium and magnesium. The specific mineral content shapes the flavor, so it can vary.

Many of our customers report that it tastes noticeably better than tap water and that they feel more hydrated with fewer sips. Water that is too alkaline (above pH 9.5 or 10) can have a slightly bitter taste, which is why our systems are designed to produce water at optimal levels for both taste and benefit. We want you to enjoy drinking it and stay consistently hydrated.

Conclusion: The Final Verdict on Alkaline Water

So, what's the bottom line on the health benefits of alkaline water? The research is genuinely promising, though more is needed for definitive conclusions. We've seen studies showing potential for digestive relief, metabolic health improvements, better hydration, and bone support.

entry.content:
Understanding Hydrogenated Water: What You Need to Know

Hydrogenated Water is regular water infused with additional molecular hydrogen gas (H2), creating a beverage with improved antioxidant properties. Here's a quick overview:

  • What it is: Pure water with extra hydrogen molecules dissolved into it.
  • How it's made: Through electrolysis or direct hydrogen gas infusion.
  • Key benefit: Acts as a selective antioxidant that neutralizes harmful free radicals.
  • Typical concentration: 0.5 to 1.5 parts per million (ppm) of dissolved hydrogen.
  • Safety: Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) by the FDA.

Once a niche product in Japan, hydrogenated water is now a growing health trend worldwide. Its appeal lies in molecular hydrogen's small size, allowing it to easily penetrate cell membranes and even the blood-brain barrier to fight oxidative stress where it's needed most.

Hundreds of peer-reviewed studies suggest molecular hydrogen acts as a therapeutic antioxidant, with potential benefits ranging from reduced inflammation to improved athletic performance. While not a cure-all, the evidence has sparked serious scientific interest. Unlike plain water, which only hydrates, hydrogenated water delivers that same hydration plus dissolved hydrogen to combat oxidative stress.

I'm Thai Cabados, and with over 20 years in water filtration technology, I've pioneered advanced alkaline hydrogen water systems in the United States. My work developing commercial-grade hydrogenated water ionizers provides unique insight into this emerging health technology.

This guide will walk you through the research on hydrogenated water, helping you make an informed decision for you and your family.

What is Hydrogenated Water and How Does It Work?

Hydrogenated water isn't about the hydrogen already bonded in H2O. It refers to extra molecular hydrogen gas (H2) dissolved into water, much like carbonation in sparkling water. This colorless, odorless, and non-toxic gas doesn't change the water's taste but works at a cellular level.

The most reliable way to create it is through electrolysis. An electric current splits H2O molecules, generating hydrogen gas that dissolves back into the water. This is how advanced water ionizer technology creates fresh, hydrogen-rich water on demand.

How Hydrogen Acts in the Body

Once consumed, these tiny H2 molecules offer benefits that larger antioxidants can't. Hydrogen is a selective antioxidant. Your body produces both harmful and beneficial free radicals. Instead of neutralizing all of them, hydrogen intelligently targets only the most destructive ones—specifically the hydroxyl radical and peroxynitrite—and converts them into harmless water. This selective process, detailed in research on molecular hydrogen, protects cells without disrupting essential functions.

What makes H2 so effective? Its size. As the smallest molecule in the universe, it easily crosses cell membranes and the blood-brain barrier, reaching mitochondria and even the cell nucleus. This exceptional bioavailability allows it to reduce oxidative stress and provide precise cell protection throughout your body.

The Science of Producing Hydrogenated Water

When considering hydrogenated water, concentration is key. Measured in parts per million (ppm), it indicates how many milligrams of H2 are dissolved per liter. The saturation point at room temperature is about 1.5 ppm, a concentration that studies suggest can produce therapeutic effects.

Water ionizers use electrolysis to generate consistent levels of hydrogen-rich water.

A major challenge is the lack of industry standards. Reported hydrogen concentrations can vary widely depending on how water is produced and handled. This makes ensuring product quality crucial. Advanced water ionizers solve this by producing verifiable levels of dissolved hydrogen right when you drink it, eliminating concerns about storage and degradation.

The Science-Backed Health Claims of Hydrogen Water

Let's examine what research reveals about hydrogenated water. While the science is still developing, several studies show encouraging findings.

Antioxidant and Anti-Inflammatory Power

The strongest evidence for hydrogenated water relates to its ability to fight oxidative stress and inflammation, which are linked to numerous chronic diseases.

For instance, a study on liver cancer patients undergoing radiation found that those drinking hydrogen-enriched water daily showed lower markers of oxidative stress and maintained higher antioxidant activity than the control group. Another study on healthy adults showed that four weeks of drinking hydrogen-rich water increased their Biological Antioxidant Potential (BAP), reduced a marker for DNA damage (8-OHdG), and lowered inflammatory cell markers. You can find more details in the scientific research on inflammatory responses.

However, not all studies show dramatic results. One four-week trial found no significant change in oxidative stress markers compared to a placebo. This suggests benefits may depend on an individual's health status and other factors.

Potential Support for Metabolic Syndrome

Metabolic syndrome—a group of conditions including high blood pressure, high blood sugar, and unhealthy cholesterol—increases the risk of heart disease and diabetes. Research on hydrogenated water in this area has been consistently positive.

A 10-week study of people with metabolic syndrome found that daily consumption of hydrogen-enriched water led to significant reductions in "bad" LDL cholesterol, increases in "good" HDL cholesterol, and reduced inflammation. Another high-quality study on metabolic syndrome involving 60 individuals confirmed these findings, showing improvements in blood glucose, cholesterol, and long-term blood sugar control (hemoglobin A1c).

While some studies have shown mixed results on fasting blood glucose, the overall evidence suggests hydrogen water could be a supportive tool for those with metabolic challenges. Larger studies are needed to confirm these benefits.

Improved Athletic Performance and Recovery

For athletes, hydrogenated water may offer an edge by reducing inflammation and lactate buildup during intense exercise. A study on male soccer players found that drinking hydrogen-enriched water led to lower blood lactate levels and less muscle fatigue. Another study with male cyclists showed they achieved greater power output during sprints after consuming hydrogen-enriched water for two weeks.

These findings, detailed in research on benefits for athletes, suggest hydrogen water could help optimize training and recovery. However, these were small studies, and the benefits might be more subtle for elite athletes already at peak condition.

Emerging Research on Anti-Aging and Brain Health

Some of the most exciting research explores hydrogen water's potential to slow aging and protect the brain. A remarkable 6-month study on older adults found that drinking just half a liter of high-concentration hydrogen water daily produced impressive results. Participants' telomeres—protective caps on chromosomes linked to aging—extended by about 4%, while they shortened in the control group.

The study also found increased levels of brain metabolites crucial for neuronal health and a tendency for improved DNA methylation, another key aging marker. Participants also showed better lower body strength. While this was a small pilot trial, the findings are compelling and warrant larger studies to confirm how hydrogenated water might support healthy aging.

A Practical Guide to Hydrogenated Water

Now that we've covered the science, let's discuss the practical aspects of adding hydrogenated water to your routine.

Comparing Hydrogenated Water to Plain Water

Plain water is essential for hydration. Hydrogenated water provides the same excellent hydration but with the added potential of therapeutic benefits from dissolved molecular hydrogen. You get the hydration your body needs, plus a potential antioxidant advantage. In terms of taste and smell, both are typically odorless and tasteless.

Here's a quick comparison:

Feature Plain Water Hydrogenated Water
Hydration Excellent, essential for life Excellent, essential for life
Antioxidant Potential None directly from water itself Potentially high, due to dissolved H2
Cost Low to moderate (tap/bottled) Higher (home devices)
Production Filtration, purification Electrolysis (advanced ionizers)
Added Therapeutic Benefits None beyond basic hydration Potential for antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, etc.

The bottom line: Plain water hydrates. Hydrogenated water aims to hydrate while also helping your body combat oxidative stress.

Why Hydrogen Concentration Is Key

Not all hydrogenated water is the same. The health benefits depend on the concentration of dissolved molecular hydrogen, measured in parts per million (ppm). While the maximum saturation is about 1.5 ppm, even this small amount has been shown to be therapeutically beneficial in studies.

The challenge is a lack of industry standards, which means claimed H2 levels can vary. This is why quality and freshness matter.

If you're investing in hydrogenated water, you need to ensure you're getting a therapeutic dose. Advanced water ionizer technology is designed to produce consistent, optimal levels of dissolved H2 on demand.

Cost vs. Benefit: Is It a Worthwhile Investment?

Home water ionizers are an upfront investment but often become more economical over time for regular users. They produce fresh, hydrogen-rich water on demand in your kitchen.

Is it worth it? The answer depends on your goals. The research shows genuine promise for improving antioxidant markers, supporting metabolic health, and aiding athletic recovery. These findings are documented in peer-reviewed studies.

However, the science is still emerging, and we need more large-scale, long-term studies. For those looking for a performance edge or managing health concerns related to oxidative stress, the current evidence may be compelling enough. For others, waiting for more definitive proof is a valid choice.

After two decades in this field, I can confirm that the technology for producing high-quality hydrogenated water has advanced significantly. Home ionizers now deliver consistent, measurable hydrogen concentrations, and the science is catching up.

Safety, Long-Term Effects, and Future Outlook

It's natural to have questions about the safety of any new wellness product. Here’s what we know about hydrogenated water.

Is Hydrogenated Water Safe to Drink?

The good news is that hydrogenated water is Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) by the FDA. Molecular hydrogen is non-toxic; in fact, our gut bacteria produce small amounts of it naturally.

Across numerous clinical trials—involving diverse groups from healthy athletes to cancer patients—no significant risks or side effects have been reported. The 6-month study on older adults, for example, found no adverse effects. Hydrogen's selective antioxidant action means it doesn't interfere with the body's beneficial processes.

Even so, it's always wise to consult your healthcare provider before making significant dietary changes, especially if you have underlying health conditions, are pregnant or nursing, or take regular medication. While no negative interactions are known, this precautionary step is always recommended.

Potential Long-Term Effects and Future of Hydrogenated Water

While short- and medium-term studies are encouraging, we don't yet have large-scale human studies tracking the effects of hydrogenated water over decades. The long-term effects are an open question that only time and further research can answer.

What we do have are promising animal models suggesting therapeutic benefits for a range of conditions, which often guide future human research. The scientific community acknowledges this knowledge gap and consistently calls for larger, more rigorous clinical trials to substantiate the preliminary findings.

The future of hydrogen medicine looks bright. Scientists are exploring its applications not just as a beverage but as a potential therapeutic agent for managing chronic diseases and supporting healthy aging. I've watched hydrogen water evolve from a curiosity into a legitimate area of scientific inquiry, and I expect that trend to continue.

The journey to fully understanding hydrogenated water is ongoing. What we know today is that it appears safe and shows promise across multiple areas of health through scientifically plausible mechanisms.

Frequently Asked Questions about Hydrogen Water

As interest in hydrogenated water grows, certain questions come up frequently. Here are answers to the most common ones.

How much hydrogen water should I drink daily?

There is no official recommended daily allowance (RDA) for hydrogenated water. However, clinical studies provide a useful guide. Study dosages have typically ranged from 0.5 to 2 liters per day (about 17 to 68 ounces), depending on the population and health goals.

For example, studies on metabolic health used about 1 liter daily, while athletic performance studies used up to 2 liters. An anti-aging study showed benefits with just 0.5 liters per day. The optimal amount likely varies based on body weight and health conditions.

A good approach is to start with a moderate amount, such as 0.5 to 1 liter per day, and see how your body responds. Hydrogenated water should complement a healthy lifestyle.

Can I make hydrogen water at home?

Yes, and making it at home is often the most convenient and cost-effective way to drink hydrogenated water regularly.

The most reliable method is using a home water ionizer, which employs electrolysis to infuse your tap water with molecular hydrogen. When choosing a system, quality is crucial, as not all ionizers produce the same concentration of dissolved hydrogen.

Advanced systems, like those with Life Ionizers' XL Matrix GRID Technology, are engineered to maximize hydrogen production and deliver therapeutically relevant concentrations. This ensures you get the most benefit from every glass.

Will drinking hydrogen water interfere with my medications?

Based on current research, there are no known negative interactions between hydrogenated water and medications. Molecular hydrogen is a non-toxic gas that your body uses or exhales; it doesn't accumulate or interfere with biological processes.

However, we strongly believe in the precautionary principle. It is always wise to consult with your doctor or healthcare provider before adding any new supplement to your routine, including hydrogenated water. This is especially important if you have chronic health conditions, take prescription medications, or are pregnant or nursing. Your doctor can provide guidance custom to your unique health situation.

Conclusion

We've explored hydrogenated water, from how molecular hydrogen acts as a selective antioxidant to the clinical research on its potential benefits for metabolic health, athletic performance, and even aging.

The science is exciting. Studies suggest hydrogenated water can reduce oxidative stress, support healthier cholesterol and blood sugar, and help athletes recover. What makes molecular hydrogen so unique is its ability to target only the most harmful free radicals, setting it apart from other antioxidants.

While the research is promising, it's also still emerging. Many studies have been small, and more large-scale trials are needed. Is hydrogenated water right for you? That's a personal decision, best made in consultation with your healthcare provider. Given that it's generally safe and the preliminary evidence is encouraging, it's certainly worth considering for those at the forefront of wellness.

entry.title: 11 Foods and Two Beverages that lower Cholesterol
entry.content:
11 Foods and Two Beverages that lower Cholesterol and Why?

Can you eat your way to lower cholesterol levels? Yes, according to a recent report from Harvard Health. Eating the right kinds of foods, and drinking the right beverages, can help you lower your cholesterol without drugs and their harmful side effects. You also have to eat less of the wrong kinds of foods and drink less of the wrong kinds of beverages.

The bad vs. the good: Confused about which kind of cholesterol is good and which is bad? Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol is bad for you (except in moderate amounts). High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol is good for you.

Exercise helps too. It raises good HDL cholesterol levels. Even moderate physical activity helps, as long as you keep at it. If you can maintain a high-intensity workout schedule, that helps even more.

Alkaline water can help lower your cholesterol! Click here for more information on cholesterol reduction and other health benefits of alkaline water

How foods can lower cholesterol levels

There are three ways that foods can lower your cholesterol levels. Some foods provide soluble fiber, which binds cholesterol and it’s precursors in the gut. Once bound, the cholesterol can then be excreted from the body in the stool. Other foods deliver polyunsaturated fats, which actually reduce levels of LDL cholesterol (the bad kind of cholesterol) in the body. Third, some foods contain plant sterols and stanols, which prevent the body from absorbing cholesterol.

Foods that lower cholesterol

Apples: Are rich in pectin, which is a type of soluble fiber

Barley and whole grains: Provide you with soluble fiber, which can help reduce your risk of heart disease along with lowering your cholesterol levels.

Beans: Are loaded with soluble fiber. They take a long time to digest, so they make you feel full longer after a meal. This makes beans a great choice for people who are trying to lose weight.

Citrus fruits: Such as oranges, grapefruit, and lemon provide pectin, which is a soluble fiber

Eggplant: Good source of soluble fiber. Note: People with arthritis may want to avoid eggplant, it’s a nightshade vegetable and can trigger painful inflammation in some people with arthritis.

Fatty fish: Eating fish lowers cholesterol by replacing the bad LDL cholesterol provided by meats with omega-3 fats, which lower cholesterol levels.

Foods fortified with sterols and stanols: Many foods have sterols and stanols added to them, your best bet is to read the label. Some examples include: chocolate, granola bars, margarine, and orange juice.

Grapes: Are rich in pectin, a non-soluble fiber.

Nuts: Eating 2 ounces of nuts per day can lower cholesterol levels by 5%. Nuts provide nutrients that are good for your heart.

Okra: Supplies non-soluble fiber.

Soy: Consuming 25 grams of soy per day can lower LDL cholesterol by 5% – 6%. 25 grams is approximately 10 ounces of tofu or 2 ½ cups of soy milk.

Two beverages that lower cholesterol levels

Tea, especially some herbal teas, and antioxidant alkaline water both can help lower cholesterol levels. In fact, you can give cholesterol a knockout “one-two punch” by making your tea with antioxidant alkaline water!

Note: Bottled alkaline water isn’t an antioxidant: You can’t get the benefits described here if you use bottled alkaline water because it has no antioxidant potential.

Antioxidant alkaline water and tea help lower cholesterol levels because they supply antioxidant potential. Antioxidants break down cholesterol which prevents it from clogging arteries and enables the body to expel it.

When you make your tea with alkaline water, it increases the number of tea catechins – antioxidant compounds from tea leaves – that you get in your tea. Making your tea with alkaline water also reduces the formation of tea cream: Deposits that form on the bottom of your teacup. Tea cream robs tea of antioxidant benefit, so making your tea with alkaline water helps preserve and increase your tea’s antioxidant benefit. For best results, use the highest pH (level 4) alkaline water your water ionizer can make. The higher the pH, the lesser tea cream forms in your cup.

Antioxidant alkaline water doubles the amount of antioxidant gallic acid in your tea. Gallic acid acts as an antioxidant, antifungal, and antiviral agent. It protects your body from harmful invaders while dissolving cholesterol. The higher the antioxidant potential of the alkaline water you use, the higher the amount of gallic acid you will have in your tea.

Top-of-the-line Life Ionizers can reach a pH level of over 11, with an antioxidant potential of over -800 ORP! Making your tea with alkaline water that powerful will maximize the health benefits of the tea.

Foods to avoid because they raise cholesterol

Saturated fats and trans fats are the two main sources of bad LDL cholesterol in foods, but the whole truth is a bit more complex than that: Saturated fats can lower triglyceride levels and boost levels of good HDL cholesterol. The best choice is to eat the foods containing saturated fats in moderation, you don’t have them avoid entirely. You should avoid foods with trans fats entirely, trans fats are not good for you in any amount.

Saturated fats: Eggs, red meats, whole fat dairy products, and oils including palm oil, coconut oil (there is some evidence for beneficial health effects from coconut oil) and cocoa butter. These foods can be part of a healthy diet when consumed in moderation.

Trans fats: Trans fats are produced by a chemical reaction that turns vegetable oil into margarine or shortening. It is well established that trans fats in any amount are bad for your heart. Trans fats increase bad LDL cholesterol and harmful triglyceride levels and decrease levels of beneficial HDL cholesterol.

The FDA recently banned trans fats from all foods: They will be phased out in three years. Until then read the label carefully on margarine, shortenings, and any pre-prepared foods.

Exercising to cut cholesterol: How much, when, and what kinds help

Regular exercise will help lower your levels of harmful LDL cholesterol and triglycerides, and at the same time, it helps increase your levels of good HDL cholesterol. Exercise also helps protect your heart; 40 minutes of moderate to vigorous aerobic exercise provides significant protection against heart disease. Combining aerobic and strength training is the best way to reduce your risk of heart disease.

How much and when: The American Heart Association (AMA) recommends an average of 40 minutes of moderate to intense aerobic activity, three or four times per week. For best results, the AMA recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise per week.

Talk to your doctor before starting any exercise regimen, and tell your doctor if you plan to engage in an intense exercise regimen. Intense training can increase your risk of heart attack if you are at risk for heart attacks.

Cholesterol reduction means a healthy lifestyle

If you are currently on cholesterol-lowering medications, don’t stop or reduce your dosage unless told to by your doctor. Quitting cholesterol-lowering medications cold turkey can have serious health consequences. Instead, inform your doctor about your plans to lower your cholesterol levels naturally. Your doctor is going to want to monitor your progress. Your doctor will tell you when, and by how much, to reduce your medications.

entry.title: What happens to water when it is ionized
entry.content:
When water in a water ionizer is ionized, it is split into two separate streams of water. One of those streams is alkaline, the other one is acidic. Why two streams of water? Because of the physics behind the ionization process. A water ionizer doesn’t add anything to water when it ionizes it, instead, the ionization process changes the composition of the mineral compounds in the water.

What water is like before it is ionized

The ionization process affects the dissolved mineral salts in water, not on the actual water molecules themselves. Tap water contains dissolved mineral salts, mostly calcium carbonates and magnesium carbonates. Those two mineral salts are responsible for the white deposits left on plumbing and appliances in homes with hard water. In general, water that contains greater than 60 milligrams per liter of those salts is considered to be moderately hard water Most homes in the US are served by water supplies that are moderately hard, or harder. Hard water is safe to drink, in fact, it is better for your health than soft water. According to the World Health Organization, you need to get between 10 – 20% of your daily needs for calcium and magnesium from your drinking water. So hard water is good for your health, but if it’s very hard, your water can taste chalky.

What happens to water when it’s ionized

The ionization process splits the mineral salts in tap water in half: The calcium and magnesium are split from the carbonate that they were combined with. Next, the calcium and magnesium ions are drawn through a special ion-permeable membrane into a separate chamber. Likewise, the carbonate ions are also drawn through the ion permeable membrane into their own separate chamber.

Alkaline water: After being separated from the carbonate ions, the calcium and magnesium ions pull hydroxyl ions from the water around them to form new mineral salts: Calcium hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide. These newly formed hydroxide salts are highly alkaline, they are what gives alkaline water its high alkaline pH. The hydroxyl ions give the alkaline water its age-defying antioxidant potential.

Acidic water: When the carbonate ions enter their chamber, they also react with water molecules. The reaction produces a solution of carbonic acid. It’s a very weak solution, that is useful as a beauty rinse, for watering plants, and for sanitizing produce.

Is bottled alkaline water the same as ionized alkaline water?

No. In fact, many bottled alkaline waters aren’t even alkaline! Tests were done on some popular brands such as Trader Joe’s bottled alkaline water actually showed that those brands could actually be acidic. The problem is that alkaline water doesn’t keep if you put it into a bottle, you have to drink it within 24 hours of making it get the water’s full potency. Even if it has an alkaline pH, bottled alkaline water doesn’t have any antioxidant potential, and that antioxidant potential is responsible for many of the health benefits that you drink alkaline water for.

The only way to get the full benefit of drinking alkaline water is to make it yourself, with a water ionizer. Consider this: You need to drink 2 – 3 liters of water per day for good health. What are PFAS?

PFAS or, “Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are a group of man-made chemicals that includes PFOA, PFOS, GenX, and many other chemicals” (1).

The most common PFAS being the chemical PFOA or “Perfluorooctanoic acid”. This chemical was used commercially to manufacture Teflon, the chemical coating that made non-stick cookware.

When exposed to heat, most non-stick cookware becomes a source of PFOA vapor, but why is this a problem?

Is Teflon Safe?

This unique polymer coating prevents food from sticking in the pans during the cooking process and at normal cooking temperatures, Teflon-coated cookware releases various gases and chemicals that present mild to severe toxicity (2).

This is a problem because PFOA from Teflon was shown to bioaccumulate in our body and is associated with various health conditions including thyroid disorders, chronic kidney disease, liver disease, testicular cancer, low birth weight, and infertility (3)(4)(5)(6)(7)(8).

As public health concerns raised the industry “phased out” PFOA laden cookware. Teflon still remains an issue even without PFOA in the making of it.

But even if you’re not using non-stick cookware, PFAS can still be a problem because these do not break down in the environment easily and end up in places such as our drinking water.

entry.content:
A 2015 scientific paper published in the Journal of Current Alzheimer’s research suggests that ionized water could assist in brain health later in life (1). But what exactly is Alzheimer’s Disease? And how on earth can ionized water help assist in brain health?

What is Alzheimer’s Disease: An Overview

At its most basic level, Alzheimer’s Disease is caused by plaque deposits and protein tangles in the brain that leads to dementia which eventually results in death. The cause of changes in the brain are largely due to oxidative stress, where an imbalance between oxidants and antioxidants create reactive oxygen species that disrupt proteins, fats, and, most importantly, DNA (2). It’s important to remember that life is built through balance. There are real benefits to having a healthy (low) level concentration of reactive oxygen species (3). They even play a role in boosting your immune system, but they can easily build to dangerous levels, especially as we age (4).

What do I need to know?

Alzheimer’s Disease is devastatingly common. In fact, it is the 6th leading cause of death in the U.S.(5). Though this is a terrifying statistic, research has established that your risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease is determined by genetics AND environmental factors (6). And this is good news! While there are genetic factors out of your control that play a role in your risk level, your risk is made variable by things like diet and exercise.

Unfortunately, there’s only so much that diet and exercise can do to prevent the development of Alzheimer’s Disease.

Why?

Because as we age, our bodies become less capable of preventing oxidative stress. When this damage builds up, it results in DNA damage and errors, which exacerbate dementia and Alzheimer’s Disease. Therefore, traditional approaches to diet and exercise may not be enough to protect your brain.

Ionized water could be another tool to assist in brain health later in life.

Is Alkaline Water REALLY the Best Way to Reduce Oxidative Stress?

As we already learned, diet and exercise do play a contributing role in reducing oxidative stress and decreasing the risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease. So, why can’t you just rely on the food you choose to eat and the exercise you choose to engage in? The answer may surprise you.

It turns out the blood brain barrier, a barrier that prevents certain substances from entering the blood circulating around the brain, plays a significant role. Though it is really important, and blocks a lot of things that have the potential to harm the brain, it can be too selective in its permeability (7). It actually blocks antioxidants consumed in food from entering the bloodstream in the brain. As a result, antioxidants from food cannot easily reduce oxidative stress in the brain. This is also true of antioxidants consumed in the form of vitamins!

Alkaline, ionized water, however, can pass through the blood-brain barrier because of the water-specific pores found along the barrier (8). This makes alkaline water the best choice for delivering powerful antioxidants (called reactive oxygen species-scavengers) to the brain.

Don’t believe it? Let’s dig a little deeper and see what the research says about the role of ionized water in reducing oxidative stress.

How Can You Reduce Your Risks?

A 2018 study in Japan found that alkaline water treatment for healthy individuals improved sleep quality, waking mood, gastrointestinal health, and it reduced oxidative stress (9).

Another study on mice with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease found that alkaline water even reduced liver damage (10). Why? Because the diatomic hydrogen in it is a powerful antioxidant which directly reduces the amount of free radicals, resulting in reduced oxidative stress (11).

It turns out that ionized water is so good at reducing oxidative stress that it has its own name. The process of electrochemically reducing water (ionizing) creates the property referred to as reactive oxygen species-scavenging (12).

And this is important! Though there have not yet been long-term studies that evaluate the direct effect of lifelong ionized water consumption and the risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease, studies show that it reduces oxidative stress. And oxidative stress is the major contributing factor in the development of Alzheimer’s Disease, and many other diseases.

These diseases include cancer, early aging, other neurodegenerative diseases, autoimmune diseases like lupus, and many more (13).

You are able to test yourself for Alzheimer’s disease and more. It is also essential that you do what you can to reduce oxidative stress for your health.

Conclusion

In this article, we’ve found out that Alzheimer’s Disease is incredibly common and serious, with 1 in 14 adults over 65 having it (14). We have also learned that the leading factor causing Alzheimer’s Disease is oxidative stress. Though food can reduce oxidative stress when a diet is rich in antioxidants, those antioxidants cannot travel through the blood brain barrier to stop oxidative stress in the brain. Alkaline water, however, can travel through the blood brain barrier.

Alkaline water is special because it is full of diatomic hydrogen (H2), which passes through the blood brain barrier and scavenges for reactive oxygen species to, essentially, deactivate them. Research has shown that alkaline water improves the health of both animal and human subjects by reducing oxidative stress. These results suggest that alkaline water could be a key preventative therapy in the development of Alzheimer’s Disease.

Should you start drinking alkaline water?

Yes. It turns out that drinking alkaline water could be one of the best things to do for your health.

entry.title: Lactic Acid and How It Impacts Exercise
entry.content:
When we exercise, many different things happen in our bodies. Some beneficial, some not. Exercise to gain strength, tone your body, or for weight loss all need to be done properly.

That’s why it is so important to follow guidelines before, during, and after exercising. Warming up, cooling down, and staying hydrated are all necessary to achieve the goals you set.

Muscle strains and other injuries can occur when you are not properly prepared. Lactic acid can also build up in your muscles, causing fatigue. While not always harmful, it can be avoided.

What is Lactic Acid?

Lactic acid, also known as lactate, happens when your body processes carbohydrates into energy without enough oxygen. It can build during over-exerting yourself during exercise.

Lactic acid build-up is temporary but it can still cause muscle fatigue and perhaps soreness. It happens during intense workouts or prolonged exercise without taking the necessary precautions.

While lactic acid build-up is not always serious, there can be more severe cases. Mild lactic acid will often start as muscle fatigue and then leads to stiff or sore muscles. But can lead to cramping, a tingling sensation, and even a burning sensation.

More severe cases can cause dizziness, weakness, severe cramping or aching muscles, shortness of breath, and even vomiting. This is a sign you are overdoing it with the exercise.

Preventing Lactic Acid

Even though lactic acid is not always a big problem, you can take a few measures to help prevent it from forming in the first place.

Warm Up

Before you exercise, you should always stretch and warm up your muscles. This helps prevent injury and allows you to get the most out of your training or exercise session.

This helps you exercise propper and the oxygen can get in your muscles and allow you to be more flexible. It will also get your circulation moving and let your muscles know they are going to work.

Stay Hydrated

Drinking plenty of water will help you while working out. It can prevent the lactic acid from building up and keep you from getting dehydrated. We don’t always notice how much we have been sweating.

Drinking ionized water can help you stay hydrated better and allow more oxygen into your body. When you work out, the pH level in your system and your muscles start to drop.

Alkaline water will stop the lactic acid that comes when your pH levels drop and there is less oxygen in your body. Drink alkaline water before, during, and after your workouts, and in between, as well.

Watch Your Breathing

The reason muscles get sore and cramped is also that there is not enough oxygen in your body. You are asking them to work hard, so they need to be prepared.

You should practice breathing exercises, even if you do it while stretching for your warm-up. Once you are aware of your breathing, it is much easier to control. It will help you stay focused and work out longer.

Rest

Even pro athletes need a day off. Don’t overdo the workouts. If you do weights one day, do cardio the next, or intersperse them with yoga or stretching. Too much will have the opposite effect on what you are trying to achieve.

Your body needs time to break down the lactic acid so make sure you have a day where you don’t do any strenuous types of exercise. Make sure you drink plenty of water during all those days, on or off.
